headline: Safety & Security in Varanasi: A First‑Person Guide
description: A detailed, first-person safety guide for tourists and solo female travellers visiting Varanasi. Covers the safest areas to stay, common scams to avoid, emergency numbers, and practical tips for a secure trip.
keywords: Varanasi safety, solo female travel India, is Varanasi safe, Varanasi scams, Varanasi tourist guide, safety in Varanasi for foreigners, Varanasi travel tips

mainEntity.name: What is the all-in-one emergency number in Varanasi?

acceptedAnswer.text: The national emergency number is 112. It is an all-in-one number for Police, Fire, and Ambulance services, similar to 911 or 999.

mainEntity.name: What is the direct number for the police in Varanasi?

acceptedAnswer.text: The direct line to the police control room is 100.

mainEntity.name: Which numbers should I call for a medical emergency?

acceptedAnswer.text: For health-related emergencies, you can call 102 or 108 for an ambulance.

mainEntity.name: Is there a dedicated helpline for women in distress?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, the helpline for women facing harassment or safety concerns is 1091 or 1090.

mainEntity.name: Is there a multi-lingual helpline for tourists?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, the National Tourist Helpline is 1363 and offers support in multiple languages.

step.name: Get a SIM Card
step.text: Your first stop after clearing immigration at Lal Bahadur Shastri Airport (VNS) should be an official Airtel or Jio kiosk. Immediate connectivity is a safety essential. Have your passport, visa, and a passport-sized photo ready. An eSIM purchased online beforehand is an even smoother option.

step.name: Secure Some Cash
step.text: Use an ATM inside the airport terminal to withdraw a few thousand rupees. Cash is essential for tuk-tuks, street food, and small purchases.

step.name: Take a Pre-Booked Taxi
step.text: The simplest scam-free option is to pre-book your cab with a reputable service like Kashi Taxi (9450301573) or use the official prepaid counter at the airport. A fixed-fare ride to the city centre costs roughly ₹800-₹1000.

step.name: Dress the Part
step.text: From the moment you arrive, dress conservatively. For women, this means loose-fitting trousers or a long skirt paired with a top that covers your shoulders. This minimizes unwanted attention.
